July 3, 1988: Fiction
ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the
49th state told in fictional form.
THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A
congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or
death.
ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St.
Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary
New York.
THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York.
LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.)
A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing
conditions.
CRIMSON JOY, by Robert B. Parker. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The private eye
Spenser in pursuit of a serial lady-killer in Boston.
PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans
in New York society and one man's role in it.
ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and
anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California.
FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) A Detroit
police detective investigates a series of crimes with its roots in the 1960's.
TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a
global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove.
THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman
and a painting tie together three generations of an English family.
PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.)
An overture to the five-volume science fiction saga about the Foundation empire.
SCORPIUS, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the tortuous trail
of a global czar of vice and terrorism.
THE CHARM SCHOOL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $17.95.) An American tourist
in the Soviet Union stumbles onto a K.G.B. plot to strike at the American
heartland.
TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New
July 3, 1988
Non-Fiction
TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.)
More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A
British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
FOR THE RECORD, by Donald T. Regan. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.)
The recollections of President Reagan's former Treasury Secretary and chief of
staff.
TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The
career and business style of the New York entrepreneur.
A TRAIL OF MEMORIES, edited by Angelique L'Amour. (Bantam, $12.95.)
Quotations from the works of Louis L'Amour, compiled by his daughter.
WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and
political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II.
RIDING THE IRON ROOSTER, by Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $21.95.) A yearlong
journey by train through China.
CAPOTE, by Gerald Clarke. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) The life of Truman
Capote.
PICASSO, by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A
portrait of the artist as ''creator and destroyer.''
SHOW TIME, by Pat Riley. (Warner, $17.95.) The coach of the Los Angeles
Lakers reviews last year's championship season.
THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random
House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great
nations in the past 500 years.
MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the
celebrated performer.
TELL IT TO THE KING, by Larry King with Peter Occhiogrosso. (Putnam, $16.95.)
Anecdotes about celebrities by the radio and television talk show host.
1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President
outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States.
ROBERT KENNEDY: In His Own Words, edited by Edwin O. Guthman and Jeffrey
Shulman. (Bantam, $22.50.) A collection of interviews with Robert Kennedy about
his career and his brother John.
